newsitem.title: USA: U.S. stocks hold gains, long weekend dampens trade.
newsitem.headline: U.S. stocks hold gains, long weekend dampens trade.

text.p: U.S. stocks guarded most early session gains by midday on Friday, as bonds held steady and smaller-capitalization issues pushed higher, but trading lost steam going into a three-day U.S. holiday weekend.

The Dow industrial average was trading up around 38 points to 7296, after an initial 50-point bounce prompted the New York Stock Exchange to set index-arbitrage curbs 10 minutes after the market opened.
But the stock market lacked momentum, with a Memorial Day holiday on Monday and an early close in the bond market today.
"People are going to take off for the long weekend and things are really going to quiet down," John Gardner, chief equity strategist for Van Lieu Capital Corp, said.
The bond market, which has recently provided direction to stocks, would shut at 1400 EDT/1800 GMT and traders said people were squaring up equity positions early in the day.
This might have contributed to the stock market's early-morning rise, traders said.
Other traders said share prices took support from bonds, as the benchmark 30-year Treasury stayed near but did not go above a critical seven percent yield.
Analysts had said if yields rose above seven percent, money managers would move funds from stocks to bond and cash.
Recent and enduring strength in shares of smaller-capitalized companies also lent some optimism to broader equity markets, analysts said.

The Russell 2000 index of smaller-capitalization issues traded up 1.68 points to 373 and the Nasdaq composite index was up five points to 1378. The Standard & Poor's 500 index was also up five points to 841.
Graham Tanaka, president of Tanaka Capital Management, said he also saw interest in defensive and technology stocks.

"Blue chips are coming back refreshed, after a pause," said Tanaka, who forecast the bull stock market continuing. "We're seeing interest in drug stocks and defensive shares. Technology and smaller-cap stocks are also doing well."
But other analysts were hesitant to read too much good news into today's price rise.
"It's just a dead day," John Cleland, chief investment strategist at Security Benefit Group of Cos, said.
Among particular issues, Westinghouse Electric led the list of active issues, after its CBS unit said Peter Lund, president of its CBS television and cable group, resigned.
Its shares were up two points at 19.
Tobacco stocks were also active, following a report which indicated tobacco talks were making progress on several key regulatory and legal issues, even though many issues remained to be settled.
Philip Morris was up 1/4 point at 45 while RJ Reynolds was up 1-1/4 to 33-1/8.

Mississippi Attorney General Mike Moore told Reuters a settlement of litigation against the tobacco industry was not imminent. But he said he hoped to know within two weeks whether a settlement could be reached.
